snippet: British officials said on Thursday that a banned substance commonly used in horses and potentially harmful to humans may have entered the food chain in small quantities.
abstract: Public health authorities in Britain say that equine painkiller phenylbutazone, or bute, was found in trace amounts in small number of British horse carcasses and may have entered food chain in France; admission worsens scandal over horse meet in European food chain.

byline.original: By DAN BILEFSKY and STEPHEN CASTLE
byline.contributor: Dan Bilefsky reported from Paris, and Stephen Castle from London. Reporting was contributed by George Calin from Bucharest, Romania; Andrew Higgins from Brussels; Douglas Dalby from Dublin; and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: British officials said on Thursday that a banned substance commonly used in horses and potentially harmful to humans may have entered the food chain in small quantities.

headline.seo: Britain Says Equine Drug May Have Entered Food Chain
headline.main: Britain Says Equine Drug May Have Entered Food Chain
headline.print_headline: Britain Says Equine Drug May Be in Food Chain
